awd_titl_txt: SHF:Small:Collaborative Research: Algorithmic Techniques for Post-Silicon Characterization Using Infrared Emissions
awd_abstract_narration:
Aggressive technology scaling has brought new challenges to the design and manufacturing of Integrated Circuits (ICs). A mounting challenge is the modeling and characterization of power consumption in face of possible operating and manufacturing variabilities. Accurate power characterization leads to extended battery life for mobile devices and to enhanced device reliability. A second challenge arises because manufacturing is increasingly outsourced to external foundries. Verifying that the manufacturer has not inserted any malware or "Trojan" circuitry that compromises the security of the final product is essential. The proposed research provides a unifying framework for these two challenges by detailed algorithmic analysis of infrared emissions from the backside of ICs. We propose techniques to convert the infrared emissions into accurate spatial and temporal power estimates, and to use the power and infrared ?fingerprints? to verify that the chip does not contain extra circuits inserted by the manufacturer, unbeknownst to the designer, that could cause a security breach. The successful completion of this project will lead to improved power modeling and characterization tools and increased confidence that there are no added malware in manufactured chips. The project will also lead to design prototypes and a large volume of valuable data and benchmarks that will be openly disseminated via NSF-funded Trust-Hub and other web-based portals. 


The methods and tools will find broad usage in the industry, government, and in academia. They will also impact the daily lives by increasing the battery lifetime and by improving the system's reliability and integrity. Education plan includes research experience for undergraduates, curriculum development, integration of material into graduate courses and emphasizing entrepreneurship within education. Recruitment and development of under-represented groups of students will be targeted.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed research develops an innovative approach for post-silicon power and trust analysis using nonintrusive infrared photonic emissions. The PIs' it overarching goal has been to develop accurate techniques for post-silicon power, thermal, and trustability characterization. Our research project realizes this goal through innovative algorithmic and experimental techniques that analyze the photonic emissions from the back-side of integrated circuits to arrive at the desired characterizations. We believe back-side die emissions provide a new dimension of data that can yield a wealth of information if processed appropriately. To realize our goal, we pursued an ambitious research plan with two main synergistic themes:

(1) Devise novel methods to translate or invert infrared thermal emissions into spatial and temporal power estimations. To address the associated challenges, we perform regularization methods to reduce the impact of measurement noise and AC lock-in techniques to reduce the blurring introduced by heat diffusion. We created thermal conditioning techniques to isolate the impact of leakage.  We also propose methods to close the loop with the design process by tuning pre-silicon power models using micro-benchmarks developed on real processors.

(2) Devise novel methods to detect the Trojan components that are intentional (malicious) alterations to the original design. The scope of the existing Trojan detection methods have been significantly improved by using the photonic side-channel measurements and the power estimates produced from Theme 1.  The anomalies are extracted by hypothesis testing. If the fluctuations in the measured power cannot be modeled by the statistical process variations and measurement noise, a Trojan flag is raised. The nominal values of the chip's characteristics and the statistical process variations and distributions (also known as golden models) are extracted from the simulation files and models. Several methods from detection and estimation theory along with the shape of the detection objective function will be developed for finding bounds for the best achievable detection. We also propose effective methods for combining Trojan detection by optical probing and other traditional Trojan tests to gain an unprecedented observability of the otherwise opaque IC internals.

The project material was integrated into PI's teaching and classes. Students have pursued their graduate degrees under this project. Several opportunities for training and development, especially for underrepresented students have been provided. The results were published in top tier peer-reviewed journals. Development of trust techniques at the hardware level impacts the security of the software, data, systems, and application in all layers. Security is a societal problem and due to the wide-spread usage of ICs in modern computing and communications, making hardware trustworthy can contribute to establishing a safer society.
